para.paratext: A party may use extrinsic evidence to establish portions of an incomplete writing which are consistent with the written portion. If the parties did not reduce their entire agreement to writing, then the parol evidence rule only protects the written portion.
O.C.G.A. § 24-3-2 states the rule as follows:

If the writing does not purport to contain all the stipulations of the contract, parol evidence shall be admissible to prove other portions thereof not inconsistent with the writing; collateral undertakings between parties of the same part among themselves would not properly be looked for in the writing.
The statute states the rule followed by the Georgia courts.[1]

Some jurisdictions require that the writing show incompleteness on its face. Some Georgia cases state that the writing must be incomplete on its face,[2] but generally the courts allow a party to show that the writing is incomplete through surrounding circumstances.[3] If the writing is incomplete on its face, then extrinsic evidence is admissible even if the writing contains a merger clause.[4]

However, in McTerry v. Free for All Missionary Baptist Church No. 1,[5] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that an “all agreements” clause precluded the application of the extrinsic evidence principle and that the contract was so indefinite and vague as to be unenforceable. The court did not follow its own precedent and cited only Curtis v. Pierce,[6] which involved a question about a collateral agreement and has been cited otherwise only as to that question.

If the subject matter of the contract falls within the statute of frauds, then the writing stands alone and cannot be supported by parol evidence[7] except to explain ambiguities in existing terms and descriptions.[8] For example, in Triple T-Bar, LLC v. DDR Southeast Springfield, LLC,[9] the Court of Appeals upheld a personal guaranty where the appellants argued the guarantee was incomplete, but where the lease and the guaranty both identified the appellants, the guaranty was incorporated into the lease, the guaranty provided that it served as an inducement for the other party to enter into the lease, and the other party would not have entered into the lease without it.

For example, litigants have challenged broad release agreements based upon the failure to name all released parties. In Lackey v. McDowell, the Georgia Supreme Court held that “[o]nly those parties named in the release will be discharged by that instrument.”[10] The Court explained that “[b]y ‘named,’ we mean being identified either by proper name or such other description as leaves no question of the identity of the party released.” The court concluded: “This should eliminate the need to inquire as to the intent of the parties to releases executed after the date of this opinion.” Thus, parol evidence is not admissible where the discharged party is unambiguously “named” in the release agreement.[11]

In Judge v. Wellman,[12] parol evidence was admissible to prove the intention of the parties where a lease agreement provided that property located at 808 Clark Avenue would be used “for residential purposes only.” In fact, there was no 808 Clark Avenue property, but the lessor did own property at 810 Clark Avenue and a contiguous tract at 204 Adkins Drive. Additionally, the property could not have been rented “for residential purposes only” because the building on the property was a commercial building. The lessee sued for losses resulting from breach of contract or fraud in the inducement and claimed that the lessor leased the 204 Adkins Drive property to him to use as a parking lot adjacent to the commercial building and then sold a portion of the 204 Adkins Drive property several days later. The Georgia Court of Appeals reversed a summary judgment for the defendant because there was a fact question as to whether the parties intended to include the 204 Adkins Drive property within the framework of the lease.

Likewise, the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and permitted parol evidence regarding the payment of legal fees where three different parties signed an agreement to obtain legal services, but no mention of the actual amount of the fees were discussed, and at trial, the evidence showed that the parties had previous dealings where the fees were settled.[13]
